allow:
Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Add Q-SYS Core integration with Angular services and components

Implemented complete Q-SYS QRWC (WebSocket Remote Control) integration:

- QSysService: Core WebSocket service with ChangeGroup pattern
  - Connects via wss:// with configurable polling (35ms default)
  - Uses ChangeGroup.AddComponentControl for control registration
  - Uses Component.Set for bidirectional control updates
  - Continuous polling with ChangeGroup.Poll for live updates
  - Selective logging (control commands only, no poll spam)

- Control models and wrappers with Angular signals
  - BooleanControl, KnobControl, TextControl, TriggerControl, etc.
  - Reactive signals for automatic UI updates
  - Type-safe control abstractions

- Example component demonstrating Q-SYS integration
  - System power toggle (SystemOnOff)
  - Volume control with debounced slider (150ms)
  - Mute toggle and motion mode display
  - Bidirectional sync with Q-SYS Core

- MCP server integration for component discovery
  - Added @q-sys/qrwc package
  - MCP tools: get_components, get_controls
  - Documentation for discovering available controls

- Comprehensive documentation
  - Updated README with Q-SYS setup instructions
  - Added QSYS-MCP-SETUP.md guide
  - Example usage patterns and control types reference

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)")

Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Add Q-SYS Component Browser with real-time component type display

Implemented comprehensive component browser with actual Q-SYS component types:

- QSysBrowserService: Manages component/control state with Angular signals
  - ComponentInfo and ControlInfo interfaces for type safety
  - Navigation state management (components â†’ controls â†’ editor)
  - Integration with QSysService for live updates

- QsysBrowser Component: Full-featured UI for browsing and editing
  - Component list with search, type badges, and control counts
  - Control list with type and direction indicators
  - Interactive control editor supporting:
    * Boolean controls (toggle buttons)
    * Knob/Level controls (slider with drag-to-update)
    * Float/Integer controls (number input)
    * Combo box controls (dropdown)
    * Text controls (text input)
  - Real-time bidirectional sync with Q-SYS Core
  - Drag prevention during slider interaction
  - Read-only control indicators

- Component Type Discovery: Extract actual types from QRWC
  - Types accessed via component._state.Type property
  - Examples: "device_controller_script", "custom_controls"
  - Fallback to "Unknown" for missing types

- Styling: Modern, responsive UI with smooth animations
  - Component/control cards with hover effects
  - Color-coded badges for types and directions
  - Loading notifications for async operations
  - Custom slider styling with hover/active states

- Documentation: Added BROWSER-USAGE.md guide

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)")

Bash(git commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
Fix combo box initial value display and add control write/subscribe support

- Fix combo box dropdowns showing blank on initial load by adding [selected] 
  attribute binding to option elements in HTML template
- Read combo box String values from actual control instances instead of 
  metadata to get current selection
- Implement HTTP POST endpoint for setting control values via WebSocket API
- Add component subscription system with per-control EventHandlers for 
  real-time updates
- Support re-subscription to components to update EventHandlers with latest logic
- Add WebSocket updates endpoint for broadcasting control changes to clients
- Identify combo boxes by checking for Choices array and set type accordingly

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")

Bash(git commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
feat: implement RPC-based control operations with ChangeGroup feedback

- Replace QRWC Component class approach with direct RPC calls \(Component class not exported\)
- Add RPC-based control setting via Component.Set with HTTP API fallback
- Implement real-time control feedback using QRWC''s ChangeGroup polling
- Add keepalive timer \(StatusGet every 30s\) to prevent connection timeout
- Start ChangeGroup polling manually when subscribing to components
- Intercept ChangeGroup poll results to emit control updates
- Support pulse trigger detection for Trig controls

Control operations now work via RPC while maintaining real-time feedback through
QRWC''s internal ChangeGroup polling system. This avoids timeout errors during
initialization while providing full control and feedback functionality.

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code]\(https://claude.com/claude-code\)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")

Bash(git commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
fix: resolve WebSocket connection to use runtime IP and fix Lua execution timeout

- Change WebSocket connections from secure \(wss://\) to non-secure \(ws://\) for local Q-SYS Core connections
- Fix WebSocketDiscoveryService to use runtime IP by converting wsUrl/updatesUrl to getters
- Fix Lua component discovery timeout by implementing async batch processing \(5 components at a time\)
- Use Timer-based batching in WebSocketComponentDiscovery.lua to avoid ''Max execution limits exceeded'' error

WebSocket URLs now correctly resolve to runtime IP \(e.g., 192.168.6.21\) instead of default IP \(192.168.104.220\).
Lua discovery script processes large component lists without timeout by yielding between batches.

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code]\(https://claude.com/claude-code\)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")

Bash(exist" errors.

Solution: Immediately stop QRWC''s automatic polling right after createQrwc\(\)
by clearing the intervalRef. We then manage polling ourselves through our
interceptor, giving us full control over when polling starts and ensuring
the correct ChangeGroup ID is always used.

This is the correct fix as mentioned by the user - QRWC starts polling as soon
as components are discovered and it''s not possible to intercept early enough,
which is why we use RPC commands and manual polling control.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")
